steps.title: Use about 3 cups (710 g) of seeds to make 1 cup (237 mL) of oil.
steps.content: Use about 3 cups (710 g) of seeds to make 1 cup (237 mL) of oil. Use more or less sesame seeds based on how much you have available and how much oil you want to yield. [1] X Research source Making 1 cup (237 mL) of sesame oil is a good amount for general cooking and skincare needs. If you want to make a lot in advance, double or triple the amount of sesame seeds.

steps.title: Bake the sesame seeds at 350 °F (177 °C) for an effortless option.
steps.content: Bake the sesame seeds at 350 °F (177 °C) for an effortless option. To do this, spread the seeds across a baking sheet. Then, place the baking sheet in the middle of your oven rack. After 5 minutes, stir up the sesame seeds so they don't burn. Then, cook them for another 10-15 minutes. Your sesame seeds are thoroughly toasted when the outside is a golden brown color. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Toast the seeds
steps.content: Toast the seeds in your stovetop to ensure they don’t overcook. Place your sesame seeds in a saucepan and set your stovetop temperature to medium. Heat up the seeds for 10-15 minutes, and continuously stir the sesame seeds with a mixing spoon as they warm up. [3] X Research source You should notice a pleasant, nutty aroma as the seeds toast. Sesame seeds will start popping out from the pan as its heated up. Use a mesh screen (like the one you use to block splattering oil) to cover the pan if you'd like.

steps.title: Remove your sesame seeds from the heat when they are golden brown.
steps.content: Remove your sesame seeds from the heat when they are golden brown. Whether you are using the stovetop or the oven, put your sesame seeds on a plate after they turn a golden brown shade. This way, the seeds cool down quicker. [4] X Research source The golden brown color is a sign that the sesame seeds are toasted properly. You can also stop cooking when you start smelling the roasted sesame seeds.

steps.title: Avoid overcooking your sesame seeds.
steps.content: Avoid overcooking your sesame seeds. If your seeds turn medium-dark brown, they are overcooked and will not produce great sesame oil. To prevent this, watch your sesame seeds closely throughout the toasting process. Remove them from heat as soon as they become a light shade of golden brown. [5] X Research source If you overcook your sesame seeds, that’s okay! Simply throw them out and try again.

steps.title: Mix every 1/4 cup (59 g) of sesame seeds with 1 cup (237 mL) of oil.
steps.content: Mix every 1/4 cup (59 g) of sesame seeds with 1 cup (237 mL) of oil. Pour your sesame seeds inside a medium or large pot. Then, pour in a cooking oil of your choice, based on the amount of sesame seeds you are using. You can use either peanut oil, sunflower seed oil, vegetable oil, or coconut oil to help you separate the oil from the sesame seeds. If you are using 3 cups (710 g) of sesame seeds, use 12 cups (3 L) of oil. All of these work well to help you extract the sesame oil.

steps.title: Heat the oil and sesame seeds on your stovetop for 5 minutes or so.
steps.content: Heat the oil and sesame seeds on your stovetop for 5 minutes or so. After you mix together the sesame seeds and cooking oil, use a medium heat setting to warm up the ingredients. Warming the sesame seeds in the oil helps extract more of the oil from the seeds. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Pour the mixture into a blender.
steps.content: Pour the mixture into a blender. Once the oil is warmed up, turn off the heat and place your blender in the sink. Carefully pour the oil and seeds from the pot into the blender, aiming to get as much as you can inside. This way, you can separate the cooking oil from the sesame oil.

steps.title: Blend up the sesame seeds until they are broken into small pieces.
steps.content: Blend up the sesame seeds until they are broken into small pieces. Put the lid on your blender and select a medium chop setting. Blend the ingredients for 1-4 minutes or until the seeds are broken down. You can stop blending when the seeds look completely crushed up, rather than in granules. The ingredients should easily mix together because of the cooking oil. If you have difficulty, try stirring the ingredients or using a higher heat setting.

steps.title: Let your ingredients sit for 45 minutes to 2 hours.
steps.content: Let your ingredients sit for 45 minutes to 2 hours. After you blend up the ingredients, let it sit in the blender for a while. The sesame oil rises to the top, and you can easily separate it after the other oil sinks to the bottom. Depending on what oil you used, the sesame oil may separate at different rates. [7] X Research source For instance, when using peanut oil, it may only take 45 minutes for your oil to separate. If using sunflower seed oil, it may take up to 2 hours.

steps.title: Pour the mixture through cheesecloth if using an oil other than peanut.
steps.content: Pour the mixture through cheesecloth if using an oil other than peanut. Pick a small- or medium-sized bowl and stretch the cheesecloth over top. Secure the cheesecloth with a string or rubber band. By doing this, you easily extract the sesame oil from the cooking oil. [8] X Research source Using cheesecloth ensures no seeds get inside your oil. Do this if you used sunflower oil, coconut oil, or vegetable oil

steps.title: Use a bowl to naturally let the oil separate if you're using peanut oil.
steps.content: Use a bowl to naturally let the oil separate if you're using peanut oil. If you used peanut oil, the separation process is slightly different. Simply pour your ingredients into a bowl, and let it sit for at least 45 minutes. At this point, the sesame oil naturally raises to the top. [9] X Research source With peanut oil, you do not need to pour the ingredients through cheesecloth since the oil easily separates on its own.

steps.title: Pour the sesame oil into an airtight container using a spoon.
steps.content: Pour the sesame oil into an airtight container using a spoon. If you poured the oil through cheesecloth, simply pour the strained sesame oil into a glass jar or plastic container. If you are using peanut oil, use a large metal spoon to transport the oil little by little into your container or jar. [10] X Research source For example, use a liter-sized mason jar with an airtight lid.

steps.title: Refrigerate your sesame seed oil to preserve its shelf life.
steps.content: Refrigerate your sesame seed oil to preserve its shelf life. If stored in your pantry, sesame oil lasts for 6-8 months. However, by putting it in your fridge, you can keep it for up to 2 years. [11] X Research source If the oil smells sour or tastes bitter, it has spoiled .
